abstract: This paper describes the 'mfold web server,' a suite of software applications for predicting the secondary structure of single-stranded nucleic acids. The server provides easy access to RNA and DNA folding and hybridization software for the scientific community.

title: Where is the land of Opportunity? The Geography of Intergenerational Mobility in the United States
authors: Chetty, Raj; Hendren, Nathaniel; Kline, Patrick; Saez, Emmanuel
subject: Economics; Sociology; Public Policy
abstract: Using administrative records for over 40 million children and their parents, this study shows that intergenerational mobility varies substantially across areas in the United States. High-mobility areas are correlated with less segregation, less income inequality, better schools, greater social capital, and greater family stability.

title: Trust as a Social Reality
subject: Sociology; Social Theory
abstract: This paper proposes a sociological conceptualization of trust, drawing from Luhmann and Barber. It argues that trust includes both emotional and cognitive dimensions and functions as a deep assumption underwriting social order, illustrated through examples like lying, family exchange, and monetary attitudes.

title: Open access research outputs receive more diverse citations
authors: Huang, Chun‐Kai; Neylon, Cameron; Montgomery, Lucy; et al.
subject: Bibliometrics; Open Science; Science Policy
abstract: By analyzing large-scale bibliographic data, this study finds a robust association between open access and increased diversity of citation sources by institutions, countries, and fields of research. Open access through repositories (Green OA) showed a stronger effect than via publisher platforms.

title: Lean Engineering: Doing the Right Thing Right
authors: McManus, Hugh; Haggerty, Al; Murman, Earll
subject: Engineering; Aerospace Engineering; Management
source: 1st International Conference on Innovation and Integration in Aerospace Sciences
abstract: This paper summarizes findings on migrating lean techniques to engineering processes. It proposes a three-part approach: creating the right products, with effective lifecycle and enterprise integration, using efficient engineering processes to improve value and affordability.

title: Urban humanities as a framework for the study of public space during the pandemic
authors: Giamarino, Christopher; Nelischer, Claire; Ramirez, Andrés F.
subject: Urban Studies; Humanities; Sociology
abstract: This article argues that urban humanities approaches (thick mapping, filmic sensing, digital storytelling) offer useful tools to overcome challenges in studying public space during crises like the COVID-19 pandemic. It develops a framework linking these practices to the production of space at multiple scales.

title: The State of the Digital Humanities: A Report and a Critique
subject: Digital Humanities; Humanities; Higher Education
abstract: This report and critique examines the rapid expansion of the digital humanities, arguing that the field lacks adequate critical awareness of its new relationship to postindustrial society and higher education, and is not ready to take up its full responsibility.

title: Open access journal publication in health and medical research and open science: benefits, challenges and limitations
authors: Logullo, Patricia; de Beyer, Jennifer A; Kirtley, Shona; et al.
subject: Medical Research; Open Science; Publishing
abstract: This paper summarizes the main benefits of open access, the routes for achieving it, and their challenges. It aims to help authors decide whether and how to choose open access for their health and medical research publications.

title: A cross-sectional analysis of Altmetric coverage of health research from Irish research organisations (2017-2023)
authors: Sharp, Melissa K.; Abuhaimed, Shaimaa; Yeoh, Beatrice; et al.
subject: Bibliometrics; Health Research; Science Communication
abstract: This study investigates the impact of health research outputs from Irish organizations using Altmetric data. It establishes publishing and altmetric trends, finding that while the average attention score was high, many outputs received no attention from tracked mediums.

title: Food and Inequality
subject: Sociology; Food Studies; Public Health
abstract: This paper reviews sociological research on the relationship between food and inequality. It examines how food systems create, sustain, and exacerbate inequalities, as well as how food can be a site of resistance and social change.

title: Rehabilitating street children: The great paradox
subject: Sociology; Education; Social Work
source: International Journal of Sociology and Anthropology
abstract: This non-empirical paper explores the feasibility of rehabilitating street children through inclusive education. It highlights the paradox that even if rehabilitation is successful, the stigmatization of street children often leaves a lasting, seemingly insurmountable scar.

title: Evolving Publics and the Practice of Public Sociology
subject: Sociology; Social Theory
abstract: This analysis explores how the changing roles of diverse publics affect the practice of public sociology. Using examples from Du Bois to contemporary Brazil, it examines the challenges and opportunities created by the evolution of surrounding 'archipelagos of publics'.

title: The Sociological Imagination in Challenging Times
subject: Sociology; Education; Pedagogy
source: The Journal of Public and Professional Sociology
abstract: This critical essay argues that recent world events have made sociology more relevant to students' lives, increasing the need for a well-developed sociological imagination. It reviews the scholarship on this concept and provides recommendations for expanding the field.

title: The State of Sociology: Evidence from Dissertation Abstracts
subject: Sociology; Bibliometrics; Higher Education
abstract: This paper describes the state of sociology as practiced in U.S. PhD-granting departments by analyzing dissertation abstracts from 2020-2024. It finds that qualitative methods are more common than quantitative, and the most frequent topics are inequality, economics, and race.

title: Design anthropology for ethics of care and emergence: Reflections from an energy transition project
subject: Design; Anthropology; Ethics
abstract: This paper describes a design anthropology approach to design ethics, understanding ethics as relational and emergent. It illustrates how unexpected ethical issues emerged in an energy transition project, challenging the researchers to navigate conflicting stakeholder needs with care and empathy.

title: Deep hanging out, mixed methods toolkit, or something else? Current ethnographic practices in US anthropology
authors: Snodgrass, Jeffrey G.; Lacy, Michael G.; Wutich, Amber; et al.
subject: Anthropology; Research Methods; Ethnography
abstract: This study examines survey responses from AAA members about their practice and teaching of cultural anthropology research methods. It reveals distinctive methodological clusters, with "deep hanging out" and a "mixed methods toolkit" remaining prominent, and a commitment to advancing methods that account for power imbalances.

title: Reviving anthropology's past: Digital archival access and ethical collaboration with Indigenous communities
authors: Sorensen, Amanda H.; Lee, Samantha; Marsh, Diana E.; et al.
subject: Anthropology; Archives; Digital Humanities; Ethics
abstract: This article documents efforts to re-envision the Council for the Preservation of Anthropological Records (CoPAR) to address trends in archival data reuse. It discusses the evolving context for data curation and new approaches for connecting researchers to anthropological data held in archives.

title: Constructing an Ethical Discipline: A Survey of Anthropology Program Requirements and Rhetorics
authors: Kucur, Ezra B.; Quave, Kylie E.; Kennedy, Sarah A.
subject: Anthropology; Education; Ethics
abstract: This study investigates the inclusion of ethics education within undergraduate anthropology programs in the US. It finds that while few programs explicitly require ethics coursework, many offer electives, but most do not visibly emphasize ethics as a core component of the major.

title: EcoLogits: Evaluating the Environmental Impacts of Generative AI
subject: Computer Science; Environmental Science; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper introduces EcoLogits, an open-source Python package designed to evaluate the environmental footprint of using Generative AI models. It estimates energy consumption and environmental impacts of GenAI API requests using a Life Cycle Assessment methodology.

title: Mid-infrared spectroscopy and machine learning for postconsumer plastics recycling
authors: Stavinski, S.; Maheshkar, A.; Thomas, S.; Dantu, S.; Velarde, E.
subject: Environmental Science; Chemistry; Machine Learning
abstract: This paper, recognized as a runner-up for the 2023 Outstanding Paper Awards by Environmental Science: Advances, explores the application of mid-infrared spectroscopy combined with machine learning techniques to improve the process of recycling post-consumer plastics.

title: Environmental Science – Advances: reflections and welcome to another year of the journal
authors: Jones, Kevin C.; Cai, Zongwei; Manaia, Celia M.
subject: Environmental Science; Publishing
abstract: This editorial reflects on the journal's progress two years after its launch, highlighting its interdisciplinary scope, emerging topic trends, key metrics, and its recent acceptance for indexing in Web of Science. It also reaffirms the publisher's commitment to a 100% open access future.

title: Younger Candidates, More Voters: The Relationship Between Candidate Age and Youth Voter Turnout
subject: Political Science; Elections; Youth Studies
abstract: This paper examines the relationship between the average age of candidates in U.S. elections and youth voter turnout. Using regression analysis, it finds that while there is a positive correlation between candidate age and youth turnout, this relationship is significantly confounded by election type (presidential vs. midterm).

title: Not just by means alone: why the evolution of distribution shapes matters for understanding opinion dynamics. The case of the French reaction to the war in Ukraine
authors: Richter, Friederike; Thiébaut, Cyrille; Safra, Lou
subject: Political Science; Public Opinion; Data Analysis
abstract: This study illustrates how analyzing the evolution of both the mean and the distribution shape of survey responses can offer complementary insights into opinion dynamics. Using the French public's perception of defense issues before and after the war in Ukraine, it shows how this approach reveals nuanced shifts.

title: Political Issues in Social Media Campaigns for National Elections: A Plea for Comparative Research
authors: Bene, Márton; Magin, Melanie; Haßler, Jörg
subject: Political Science; Political Communication; Social Media
abstract: This editorial introduces a thematic issue examining how political parties use social media to promote issues during election campaigns. Based on a comparative research project covering 14 countries, it highlights diverse approaches to issue-based communication on social media.

title: Mary Warnock and 'public philosophy'
subject: Philosophy; Ethics; Public Policy
abstract: This article responds to the characterization of Mary Warnock as a public intellectual whose achievements came at the expense of philosophical rigor. It analyzes her view of ethics, the role of feelings in moral judgments, and her distinction between private and public moral attitudes, defending her against criticism.

title: Interpretative Phenomenological/Phronesis Analyses: Using Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) to Position Research Participant Experiential Narratives
authors: Md Syed, Md Azalanshah Bin; Wilson, Tony
subject: Philosophy; Research Methods; Hermeneutics
abstract: This paper proposes eight Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) derived from hermeneutic philosophers (Aristotle, Heidegger, Gadamer, Ricoeur) to systematically assist in the thematic analysis of experiential narratives within Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis (IPA).

title: Translation Notes: Heidegger, Derrida, and the Chance for (a) Philosophy
subject: Philosophy; Translation Studies; Deconstruction
abstract: This paper argues that translation is both a philosophical problem and a specific philosophical praxis. It considers the philosophies of Heidegger and Derrida, showing how Derrida's challenge to Heidegger's view of translation as a 'shipwreck' opens new paths for philosophical investigation.

title: Writing in Philosophy: Pedagogy and Practice
authors: Donovan, Sarah K. (ed.); Smith, Renée J. (ed.)
subject: Philosophy; Education; Pedagogy
abstract: This volume provides instructors with a resource for teaching writing in the philosophy classroom. It offers a variety of pedagogical approaches, including creative alternatives to traditional papers and strategies for inclusive practice, to help students develop essential writing skills for doing philosophy.

title: pi-Flow: Policy-Based Few-Step Generation via Imitation Distillation
authors: Chen, Hansheng; Zhang, Kai; Tan, Hao; Guibas, Leonidas; Wetzstein, Gordon; Bi, Sai
subject: Machine Learning; Artificial Intelligence; Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
abstract: N/A

title: Identity-Link IRT for Label-Free LLM Evaluation: Preserving Additivity in TVD-MI Scores
subject: Machine Learning; Machine Learning (stat.ML)
abstract: Pairwise comparisons of large language models using total variation distance mutual information (TVD-MI) produces binary critic decisions per pair. We show averaging TVD-MI's binary trials yields centered-probability scores with an additive structure suitable for Item-Response Theory (IRT) without needing non-linear link functions.

title: Updating the Definition of Cancer
authors: Amend, S. R.; Sjøstrom, K.; Pienta, K. J.; Amend, M.
subject: Cancer Biology; Genetics
abstract: We propose a revised definition of cancer: Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled proliferation by transformed cells subject to evolution by natural selection. We believe this definition captures the essence of the majority of previous and current definitions.

title: Revolutionizing Cancer Treatment: Recent Advances in Immunotherapy
authors: Ghemrawi, Rose; Abuamer, Lama; Kremesh, Sedra; Hussien, Ghadeer; Ahmed, Rahaf; Mousa, Walaa; Khoder, Ghalia; Khair, Mostafa
subject: Cancer; Immunotherapy; Oncology
abstract: This review explores the scope and impact of various immunotherapeutic strategies, including monoclonal antibodies, chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cell therapy, checkpoint inhibitors, cytokine therapy, and therapeutic vaccines.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Health Care: Applications and Legal Implications
subject: Computer Law; Health Law and Policy; Science and Technology Law
abstract: This article briefly describes the concept of AI in medicine, including several possible applications, then considers its legal implications in four areas of law: regulation, tort, intellectual property, and privacy.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Autonomy
subject: Law; Artificial Intelligence; Technology
abstract: This article explores the challenges posed by autonomous systems, including autonomous vehicles, weapons, and algorithmic decision-making, and considers how existing legal and regulatory frameworks may need to be adapted.

title: Biology-informed neural networks learn nonlinear representations from omics data to improve genomic prediction and interpretability
authors: Kontolati, Katiana; Gladstone, Rini Jasmine; Davis, Ian; Pickering, Ethan
subject: Machine Learning; Biology
abstract: N/A

title: World Cancer Report: Cancer research for cancer prevention
authors: Wild, Christopher P.; Weiderpass, Elisabete; Stewart, Bernard W.
subject: Cancer; Public Health; Medicine
abstract: This publication provides wide-ranging insights into cancer prevention based on the known causes of cancer, factors that determine how cancer develops, and the behaviour of different tumour types, and presents a broad scope of interventions.

title: IMPLEMENTING ETHICS INTO ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
subject: Law; Ethics; Artificial Intelligence; Governance
abstract: This Article advocates for the need to conduct in-depth risk-benefit-assessments with regard to the use of AI and autonomous systems and develops a graded governance model for the implementation of ethical concerns in AI systems.

title: Analyzing Research Trends in Computer Science
subject: Computer Science; Data Mining; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper analyzes the self-reported research interests of the top 3,260 most cited computer science scholars. By leveraging the scholarly Python library, we systematically retrieved and classified each researcher's interests into predefined categories grounded in the Computer Science Ontology (CSO). Our results reveal a clear hierarchy of primary focus areas such as Artificial Intelligence, Software Engineering, and Data Mining.

title: Towards Integrating Emerging AI Applications in SE Education
subject: Computer Science; Software Engineering; Artificial Intelligence; Education
abstract: In this early research paper, we present preliminary results of a systematic analysis of current trends in the area of AI, and how they can be integrated into university-level Software Engineering (SE) curricula, guidelines, and approaches to support both instructors and learners.

title: The Shallow and the Deep: A biased introduction to neural networks and old school machine learning
subject: Computer Science; Machine Learning; Neural Networks
abstract: The Shallow and the Deep is a collection of lecture notes that offers an accessible introduction to neural networks and machine learning in general. The focus lies on classical machine learning techniques, with a bias towards classification and regression.

title: Think Python: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist - 2e
subject: Computer Science; Programming; Python
abstract: Think Python is a concise introduction to software design using the Python programming language. Intended for people with no programming experience, this book starts with the most basic concepts and gradually adds new material.

title: Scientific Computing for Chemists with Python
subject: Computer Science; Chemistry; Python
abstract: This book serves as an introduction to coding for chemists. The tools employed in this book are the powerful and popular combination of Jupyter notebooks and the Python programming language.

title: Mathematics for Elementary Teachers
subject: Education; Mathematics
abstract: This book will help you to understand elementary mathematics more deeply, gain facility with creating and using mathematical notation, develop a habit of looking for reasons and creating mathematical explanations, and become more comfortable exploring unfamiliar mathematical situations.

title: Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python
authors: Bell, Ana; Grimson, Eric; Guttag, John
subject: Computer Science; Programming; Python
abstract: This course is an introduction to computer science as a tool to solve real-world analytical problems using Python 3.5.

title: A Vision of Linear Algebra
subject: Mathematics; Linear Algebra
abstract: This course is a new way of learning linear algebra. The key is to see the whole picture of the subject—the five crucial factorizations of a matrix.

title: The Analytics Edge
subject: Business; Management; Data Science; Statistics
abstract: This course is about the science of data-driven decision-making. It covers topics from linear regression and logistic regression to text analytics and clustering.

title: First-Principles Approach for Coupled Quantum Dynamics of Electrons and Protons
subject: Physics; Chemistry; Quantum Mechanics
abstract: We extend real-time nuclear-electronic orbital time-dependent density functional theory (RT-NEO-TDDFT) to periodic systems and perform first-principles simulations of coupled quantum dynamics of electrons and protons in complex heterogeneous systems.

title: Accelerated Sparse Recovery via Gradient Descent with Nonlinear Conjugate Gradient Momentum
subject: Mathematics; Optimization; Machine Learning
abstract: This paper applies an idea of adaptive momentum for the nonlinear conjugate gradient to accelerate optimization problems in sparse recovery. We consider two types of minimization problems: a differentiable function and the sum of a non-smooth and a differentiable function.

title: Biology 2e
authors: Clark, Mary Ann; Choi, Jung; Douglas, Matthew
subject: Natural Sciences; Biology
abstract: Biology 2e is designed to cover the scope and sequence requirements of a typical two-semester biology course for science majors. The text provides comprehensive coverage of foundational research and core biology concepts through an evolutionary lens.

title: Chemistry 2e
authors: Flowers, Paul; Theopold, Klaus; Langley, Richard; Robinson, William R.
subject: Natural Sciences; Chemistry
abstract: Chemistry 2e is designed to meet the scope and sequence requirements of the two-semester general chemistry course. The textbook provides an important opportunity for students to learn the core concepts of chemistry and understand how those concepts apply to their lives and the world around them.

title: Business Writing for Everyone
subject: Business; Communication & Writing
abstract: An inclusive guide to writing in the workplace. The book takes a process-oriented, storytelling approach to composition: focusing less on genre and more on the decisions that effective business communicators make.

title: Managerial Accounting
subject: Business; Accounting
abstract: This book is for students who want to learn accounting in the most efficient way possible, balancing coursework with personal schedules. It delivers a modern look at managerial accounting while addressing the renewed focus on ethical behavior.

title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering and Computer Science I: Lecture Videos
authors: Kaelbling, Leslie; White, Jacob; Abelson, Harold; Freeman, Dennis; Lozano-Pérez, Tomás; Chuang, Isaac
subject: Engineering; Electrical Engineering; Computer Science; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This course provides an integrated introduction to electrical engineering and computer science, taught using substantial laboratory experiments with mobile robots. The primary goal is to learn to appreciate and use the fundamental design principles of modularity and abstraction.

title: Introductory Biology: Lecture Notes
authors: Imperiali, Barbara; Martin, Adam; Ray, Diviya
subject: Science; Biology; Health and Medicine
abstract: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of biology. It emphasizes the molecular mechanisms of heredity, gene expression, and metabolism, and also examines the cellular basis of physiology and development.

title: Principles of Economics 3e
subject: Social Sciences; Economics
abstract: Principles of Economics 3e covers the scope and sequence of most introductory economics courses. The authors take a balanced approach to micro- and macroeconomics, to both Keynesian and classical views, and to the theory and application of economics concepts.

title: Introduction to Philosophy
subject: Humanities; Philosophy
abstract: This book is a collection of chapters on the classic philosophical questions, written by several authors and edited by Christina Hendricks. It covers topics in metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and political philosophy.

title: Financial Strategy for Public Managers
subject: Business; Finance; Public Administration
abstract: A thorough, applied, and concise introduction to the essential financial concepts and analytical tools needed by effective public servants. It assumes no prior financial management knowledge or experience.

title: Matrix Calculus for Machine Learning and Beyond
subject: Mathematics; Applied Mathematics; Calculus
abstract: This course provides a background in matrix calculus, a notation that is critical for expressing and solving problems in machine learning, optimization, and many other fields.

title: Psychology 2e
authors: Spielman, Rose M.; Jenkins, William J.; Lovett, Marilyn D.
subject: Social Sciences; Psychology
abstract: Psychology 2e is designed to meet the scope and sequence requirements for the single-semester introduction to psychology course. The book offers a comprehensive treatment of core concepts, grounded in both classic studies and current and emerging research.

title: College Algebra 2e
subject: Mathematics; Algebra
abstract: Study algebra online free by downloading OpenStax's College Algebra 2e book and using our accompanying online resources including an algebra study guide.

title: Principles of Accounting, Volume 1: Financial Accounting
subject: Business; Accounting
abstract: Principles of Accounting, Volume 1: Financial Accounting covers the fundamentals of financial accounting, including the accounting cycle, financial statements, and analysis.

title: Introduction to Sociology 3e
subject: Social Sciences; Sociology
abstract: Introduction to Sociology 3e aligns to the topics and objectives of many introductory sociology courses. It is arranged in a manner that provides foundational sociological theories and contexts, then progresses through various aspects of human society.

title: Hybrid-Flexible Course Design
subject: Education; Instructional Design
abstract: This volume provides readers with methods, case stories, and strategies related to Hybrid-Flexible (HyFlex) course design so that they may make decisions about using it themselves and even begin their own HyFlex course (re)design.

title: Writing Instruction Tips For Automated Essay Graders
subject: Education; Writing; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: As schools, as well as the workplace, become more automated, and remote or distance learning/working becomes the “new normal,” understanding and leveraging artificial intelligence will become a critical skill.

title: Introduction to Tourism and Hospitality in B.C. – 2nd Edition
subject: Business; Tourism; Hospitality
abstract: This is a second edition of an open textbook first published by BCcampus in 2015, updated to be more timely and improved with interactive H5P activities.

title: Fundamentals of Materials Science
subject: Engineering; Materials Science and Engineering; Thermodynamics
abstract: This course focuses on the fundamentals of structure, energetics, and bonding that underpin materials science. It is the introductory lecture class for sophomore students in Materials Science and Engineering.

title: Structure of Materials
subject: Engineering; Materials Science and Engineering
abstract: This three-part course explores the structure of a wide variety of materials with current-day engineering applications. Part 1 of the course introduces amorphous materials and explores glasses and polymers.

title: Learn to Build Your Own Videogame with the Unity Game Engine
authors: Keane, Kyle; Ringler, Andrew; Gandhi, Abhinav; Vrablic, Mark
subject: Engineering; Computer Science; Game Design
abstract: This course provides an overview of the Unity game engine and how to work with the software interface. This is provided to help students get started on an even footing when jumping into the guided tutorial.

title: Business Fundamentals
subject: Business
abstract: Business Fundamentals is an all-encompassing introductory textbook designed to introduce readers to the business world. Geared toward college and university students, especially those with little to no prior experience in business.

title: Accounting Principles: A Business Perspective
subject: Business; Accounting
abstract: Accounting Principles: A Business Perspective uses annual reports of real companies to illustrate many of the accounting concepts in use in business today.

title: Population Health for Nurses
authors: Jessica Ochs; Sherry L. Roper; Susan M. Schwartz
subject: Nursing; Population Health
abstract: This book introduces the topic of population health, explaining that nurses play a central role in advancing it. It distinguishes population health nursing from public/community health and introduces the Healthy People 2030 program.

title: Clinical Nursing Skills
subject: Nursing
abstract: This book showcases the multifaceted nature of nursing practice. It covers the principles of nursing practice, including person-centered care, professional integrity, and lifelong learning, as well as evidence-based practice and the nursing process.

title: Maternal Newborn Nursing
authors: Amy Giles; Regina Prusinski; Laura Wallace
subject: Nursing
abstract: This book encompasses the lifespan of those assigned female at birth (AFAB), focusing on contraception, preconception care, and preventive health care. It highlights the role of nurses as advocates for their patients.

title: Pharmacology for Nurses
authors: Tina Barbour-Taylor; Leah Mueller (Sabato); Donna Paris; Dorie Weaver
subject: Nursing; Pharmacology
abstract: This book aims to provide a fundamental understanding of the pharmacological use of drugs that a nurse needs to provide safe and effective care, reviewing the pathophysiology of various disease processes and the medications used in treatment.

title: Astronomy 2e
authors: Andrew Fraknoi; David Morrison; Sidney Wolff
subject: Science; Astronomy
abstract: A study of the objects that lie beyond planet Earth and the processes by which these objects interact with one another, emphasizing that science is a "progress report" and tracing the evolutionary processes that shape the universe.

title: Biology for AP® Courses
subject: Science; Biology; AP
abstract: This textbook covers the scope and sequence requirements of a typical two-semester Advanced Placement® biology course, offering comprehensive coverage of foundational research and core biology concepts through an evolutionary lens.

title: Chemistry: Atoms First 2e
authors: Paul Flowers; Edward J. Neth; William R. Robinson, PhD; Klaus Theopold; Richard Langley
subject: Science; Chemistry
abstract: An introductory textbook that presents atomic and molecular structure much earlier than the traditional approach, linking these topics in subsequent chapters to provide students with a foundation to understand the application of quantitative principles.

title: Organic Chemistry
subject: Science; Chemistry
abstract: Renowned for being the most clearly written book available for organic chemistry, this text meets the scope and sequence of a two-semester organic chemistry course that follows a functional group approach, updated with new scientific discoveries and applications.

title: American Government 3e
subject: Social Sciences; Political Science
abstract: This book provides a comprehensive introduction to the U.S. system of government, covering foundational principles, political behavior, and the institutions of government, with a focus on meaningful engagement with the material.

title: Introduction to Anthropology
authors: Jennifer Hasty; David G. Lewis; Marjorie M. Snipes
subject: Social Sciences; Anthropology
abstract: A four-field text integrating diverse voices, engaging field activities, and meaningful themes like Indigenous experiences and social inequality to engage students and enrich learning about the study of humanity.

title: Introduction to Political Science
authors: Mark Carl Rom; Masaki Hidaka; Rachel Bzostek Walker
subject: Social Sciences; Political Science
abstract: This text serves as an introduction to the world of politics and the systematic study of political science, teaching fundamental principles and core concepts to help students become better-prepared citizens and political actors.

title: Contemporary Mathematics
subject: Mathematics
abstract: This book introduces concepts of contemporary mathematics, beginning with set theory and Venn diagrams, which are graphical ways to show relationships between different groups and are foundational to statistical studies.

title: University Physics Volume 1
authors: William Moebs; Samuel J. Ling; Jeff Sanny
subject: Science; Physics
abstract: The first of a three-volume set designed for a two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course. Volume 1 covers mechanics, sound, oscillations, and waves.

title: University Physics Volume 2
authors: Samuel J. Ling; William Moebs; Jeff Sanny
subject: Science; Physics
abstract: The second of a three-volume set designed for a two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course. Volume 2 covers thermodynamics, electricity, and magnetism.

title: University Physics Volume 3
authors: William Moebs; Samuel J. Ling; Jeff Sanny
subject: Science; Physics
abstract: The third of a three-volume set designed for a two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course. Volume 3 covers optics and modern physics.

title: Workplace Software and Skills
authors: Tammie Bolling; Angela Mitchell; Tanya Scott; Nyrobi Wheeler
subject: Business; Computer Science
abstract: This book covers fundamental computing skills needed in a modern corporate environment, including basic functions in Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace, as well as topics like computer hardware, networks, and the ethical use of technology.

title: U.S. History
authors: P. Scott Corbett; Volker Janssen; John M. Lund; Todd Pfannestiel; Sylvie Waskiewicz; Paul Vickery
subject: Humanities; History
abstract: This textbook covers the breadth of the chronological history of the United States and provides the necessary depth to ensure the course is manageable for instructors and students alike.

title: World History Volume 1, to 1500
authors: Ann Kordas; Ryan J. Lynch; Brooke Nelson; Julie Tatlock
subject: Humanities; History
abstract: The first of a two-volume set, this book explores human history from its origins to the year 1500, emphasizing a global perspective, primary sources, and the concepts of causation and interpretation in history.

title: World History Volume 2, from 1400
authors: Ann Kordas; Ryan J. Lynch; Brooke Nelson; Julie Tatlock
subject: Humanities; History
abstract: The second of a two-volume set, this book explores human history from the year 1400 to the present, emphasizing a global perspective, primary sources, and the concepts of causation and interpretation in history.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Intellectual Property: An Economic Perspective
authors: Alexander Cuntz; Carsten Fink; Hansueli Stamm
subject: Economics; Law; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper dissects AI's role as both a facilitator and disruptor of innovation and creativity, exploring the evolving landscape of AI innovation incentives and the challenges it poses to existing IP frameworks from an economic perspective.

title: Access to science and innovation in the developing world
authors: Alessio Muscarnera; Alexander Cuntz; Frank Mueller-Langer; Marc Scheufen; Prince C. Oguguo
subject: Economics; Science Policy
abstract: This paper examines the implications of lowering barriers to online access to scientific publications for science and innovation in developing countries, finding that free or reduced-fee access increases scientific publication and clinical trials output.

title: Innovation Policies Under Economic Complexity
authors: Christian Chacua; Matte Hartog; Muhammed A. Yildirim; Ricardo Hausmann; Shreyas Gadgin Matha
subject: Economics; Innovation Policy
abstract: This paper discusses the design of innovation policies to address current development challenges, arguing that effective policies should be place-based and multidimensional, leveraging countries' existing capabilities.

title: Global Trends in Innovation Patterns: A Complexity Approach
authors: Christian Chacua; Matte Hartog; Muhammed A. Yildirim; Ricardo Hausmann; Shreyas Gadgin Matha
subject: Economics; Innovation
abstract: This paper analyzes the trajectories of scientific publications, patents, and international trade data to provide a comprehensive understanding of the innovation process, from idea generation to commercialization.

title: Can we map innovation capabilities?
authors: Christian Chacua; Eduardo Hernandez Rodriguez; Federico Moscatelli; Julio Raffo; Matte Hartog; Muhammed A. Yildirim; Shreyas Gadgin Matha
subject: Economics; Innovation
abstract: This paper proposes a methodological framework to empirically measure innovation capabilities across science, technology, and production domains, leveraging data on scientific publications, patents, and trade.

title: Statutory Religious Accommodation in Employment and the Problems of Judicial Intent and Outcome
subject: Law; Civil Rights
abstract: This article discusses the Supreme Court case of Groff v. DeJoy, analyzing the Court's endorsement of a “substantial burden” test for an employer's undue hardship in religious accommodation cases.

title: Jobless Development
authors: Franziska Ohnsorge; Richard Rogerson; Zoe Leiyu Xie
subject: Economics
abstract: This paper shows that there are large differences in medium-run dynamics in the employment-to-population ratio across countries and finds a general tendency for productivity growth to be negatively correlated with changes in this ratio for many emerging market and developing economies.

title: Private Attribute Inference from Images with Vision-Language Models
authors: Batuhan Tömekçe; Mark Vero; Robin Staab; Martin Vechev
subject: Machine Learning; Computer Vision; Privacy
abstract: This paper systematically analyzes the capability of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to infer private information from inconspicuous images, finding they can infer various personal attributes at up to 77.6% accuracy, and that accuracy scales with model capabilities.

title: Scaling transformer neural networks for skillful and reliable medium-range weather forecasting
authors: Tung Nguyen; Rohan Shah; Hritik Bansal; Troy Arcomano; Romit Maulik; Rao Kotamarthi; Ian Foster; Sandeep Madireddy; Aditya Grover
subject: Machine Learning; Climate Science
abstract: This paper introduces Stormer, a simple transformer model that achieves state-of-the-art performance on weather forecasting with minimal changes to the standard transformer backbone, identifying key components through careful empirical analyses.

title: Toward Efficient Inference for Mixture of Experts
authors: Haiyang Huang; Newsha Ardalani; Anna Sun; Liu Ke; Shruti Bhosale; Hsien-Hsin Lee; Carole-Jean Wu; Benjamin Lee
subject: Machine Learning; Computer Systems
abstract: This paper explores optimizations for Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) inference to improve token throughput, memory use, and load balance without degrading model quality, proposing techniques like Dynamic Gating and Expert Buffering.

title: Learning Formal Mathematics From Intrinsic Motivation
authors: Gabriel Poesia; David Broman; Nick Haber; Noah Goodman
subject: Artificial Intelligence; Machine Learning
abstract: This paper describes an AI agent that jointly learns to pose challenging mathematical problems for itself (conjecturing) and solve them (theorem proving), bootstrapping from only the axioms of a domain without human-created proofs.

title: PRODuctive bandits: Importance Weighting No More
subject: Machine Learning
abstract: This paper challenges the conjecture that the Prod algorithm is sub-optimal for multi-armed bandits, presenting variants that can obtain optimal regret for adversarial bandits and achieve best-of-both-worlds guarantees.

title: Random Function Descent
subject: Machine Learning; Optimization
abstract: This paper bridges the gap between Bayesian optimization and classical optimization by using a 'stochastic Taylor approximation' to rediscover gradient descent, yielding a step size schedule called Random Function Descent (RFD).

title: Fully Distributed, Flexible Compositional Visual Representations via Soft Tensor Products
authors: Bethia Sun; M. Pagnucco; Y. Song
subject: Machine Learning; Computer Vision
abstract: This paper introduces Soft TPR, a representational form that encodes compositional structure in a distributed, flexible manner, and an autoencoder architecture designed to learn these representations, outperforming conventional disentanglement alternatives.

title: Toward Approaches to Scalability in 3D Human Pose Estimation
subject: Computer Vision; Machine Learning
abstract: This paper addresses key bottlenecks to scalability in 3D Human Pose Estimation (HPE), including limited data diversity and depth ambiguity, by introducing a Biomechanical Pose Generator (BPG) and Binary Depth Coordinates (BDC).

title: The Future of Jobs Report 2025
subject: Economics; Labor Market; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This report provides a comprehensive analysis of the interconnected trends shaping the global labour market for the 2025-2030 period, drawing from a survey of over 1,000 employers. It examines how macrotrends like AI, the green transition, and geoeconomic shifts impact jobs and skills, forecasting which roles will grow and decline.

title: The Sustainable Development Goals Report 2025
subject: Public Policy; Sustainable Development; Economics
abstract: This report marks the tenth annual stocktaking of global progress toward the 2030 Agenda. It provides a stark assessment that while the SDGs have improved millions of lives, the current pace of change is insufficient. It calls for action in six priority areas: food systems, energy access, digital transformation, education, jobs, and climate/biodiversity.

title: Collective funding models for open access books: Librarians’ experiences and barriers to participation across six European contexts
authors: Fathallah, Judith; Deville, Joe; Penier, Izabella; Corazza, Francesca
subject: Publishing; Open Access; Library Science
abstract: This report explores librarians' experiences with collective funding models for open access (OA) books across six European contexts. It identifies barriers to participation, such as budget pressures and the dominance of transformative agreements, and notes a strong commitment to the idea of an OA knowledge commons despite eroded trust from corporate buyouts.

title: Prevalence of and factors influencing social anxiety among Chinese college students: a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis
authors: Liu, Jie; Tao, Li; Zhu, Mengting; Lin, Qiao; He, Jiali
subject: Social Science; Mental Health; Public Health
abstract: This protocol outlines a systematic review and meta-analysis to consolidate evidence on the prevalence and determinants of social anxiety among Chinese college students. It aims to address a gap in culturally tailored analyses and inform targeted interventions, given the unique stressors this group faces.

title: Explosion of formulaic research articles, including inappropriate study designs and false discoveries, based on the NHANES US national health database
authors: Suchak, Tulsi; Aliu, Anietie E.; Harrison, Charlie; Zwiggelaar, Reyer; Geifman, Nophar; Spick, Matt
subject: Biology; Science Policy; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This meta-research article identifies a surge in formulaic, single-factor analyses using the NHANES dataset, potentially driven by AI-assisted workflows and paper mills. It highlights risks of inappropriate study designs, selective data usage, and a failure to correct for false discoveries, proposing best practices for researchers, publishers, and peer reviewers.

title: The 2025 Nucleic Acids Research database issue and the online molecular biology database collection
authors: Rigden, Daniel J.; Fernández, Xosé M.
subject: Biology; Bioinformatics; Databases
abstract: This editorial introduces the 2025 NAR database issue, which contains 185 papers covering 73 new databases and 101 updates to existing resources across all of biology. It highlights new resources in genomics, proteomics, and structural biology, and notes the 25th anniversary of the RefSeq resource.

title: PRESIDING OVER A LEGAL DESERT: THE DISAPPEARANCE OF THE RURAL ATTORNEY
subject: Law; Legal Services; Rural Sociology
abstract: This article discusses the observed effects, challenges, and inequalities that occur in and outside of the courtroom because of the lack of rural legal representation. It uses rural New Mexico as a microcosm to explore the issues confronting the nation regarding "legal deserts."

title: Generative AI and Legal Aid: Results from a Field Study and 100 Use Cases to Bridge the Access to Justice Gap
subject: Law; Artificial Intelligence; Access to Justice
source: Loyola of Los Angeles Law Review
abstract: This paper presents the first field study of lawyers using generative AI to address the access to justice gap. It finds that 90% of pilot participants reported increased productivity and discusses how legal aid professionals managed risks by focusing on lower-risk applications.

title: Understanding the Attention Economy and its Negative Effects: Consumerism is Consuming Us
subject: Economics; Sociology; Media Studies
abstract: This paper explores how the attention economy, a product of capitalism, consumes its participants. It argues that despite unprecedented physical security, people are bored and miserable due to smart technology invading their lives and privacy, exchanging happiness for mental insecurity.

title: Constructing an Ethical Discipline: A Survey of Anthropology Program Requirements and Rhetorics
authors: Kucur, Ezra B.; Quave, Kylie E.; Kennedy, Sarah A.
subject: Anthropology; Education; Ethics
abstract: This study investigates the inclusion of ethics education within undergraduate anthropology programs in the US. It finds that while few programs explicitly require ethics coursework, many offer electives, but most do not visibly emphasize ethics as a core component of the major.

title: EcoLogits: Evaluating the Environmental Impacts of Generative AI
subject: Computer Science; Environmental Science; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper introduces EcoLogits, an open-source Python package designed to evaluate the environmental footprint of using Generative AI models. It estimates energy consumption and environmental impacts of GenAI API requests using a Life Cycle Assessment methodology.

title: A cross-sectional analysis of Altmetric coverage of health research from Irish research organisations (2017-2023)
authors: Sharp, Melissa K.; Abuhaimed, Shaimaa; Yeoh, Beatrice; et al.
subject: Bibliometrics; Health Research; Science Communication
abstract: This study investigates the impact of health research outputs from Irish organizations using Altmetric data. It establishes publishing and altmetric trends, finding that while the average attention score was high, many outputs received no attention from tracked mediums.

title: Biology Open 2024 – a year in review
subject: Biology; Publishing; Peer Review
abstract: This editorial reviews the performance of the journal Biology Open for the year 2024, focusing on improving the author experience through rapid and transparent peer review. It presents publication data for 2024, noting an overall acceptance rate of approximately 30% and a drop in the median time to editorial rejection.

title: Quarterly Economic Commentary, Summer 2025
authors: Barrett, Alan; O'Toole, Conor; O'Shea, Dónal
subject: Economics; Public Policy
abstract: This commentary provides forecasts for the Irish economy for 2025 and 2026. It notes ongoing strength but revises growth forecasts downward due to international uncertainty. It projects growth in Modified Domestic Demand (MDD), continued low unemployment, and real wage growth, while highlighting risks in housing and public finance.

title: NATURAL AND NEUTRAL REAL INTEREST RATES: PAST AND FUTURE
subject: Economics; Monetary Policy
abstract: This paper surveys the decline in real interest rates in advanced and emerging economies, linking the process to various global factors. It argues that long-run equilibrium rates may not always guide short-term policy and discusses whether recent trends like geopolitical tensions and AI-driven productivity will lead to a durable rise in global real interest rates.

title: Bridging the Gap between Industry and Education: Best Practices for the Digital Humanities
authors: Goicoechea, María; Sanz, Amelia; van der Lek, Iulianna; et al.
subject: Digital Humanities; Education; Industry
abstract: This white paper outlines recommendations to align Digital Humanities (DH) education more closely with industry needs. Based on studies conducted between 2023 and 2025, it offers practical guidance for universities, students, and employers to enhance the employability of DH graduates and foster knowledge exchange.

title: Population Health for Nurses
authors: Ochs, Jessica; Roper, Sherry L.; Schwartz, Susan M.
subject: Nursing; Population Health
abstract: This book introduces the topic of population health, explaining that nurses play a central role in advancing it. It distinguishes population health nursing from public/community health and introduces the Healthy People 2030 program.

title: Clinical Nursing Skills
subject: Nursing
abstract: This book showcases the multifaceted nature of nursing practice. It covers the principles of nursing practice, including person-centered care, professional integrity, and lifelong learning, as well as evidence-based practice and the nursing process.

title: Maternal Newborn Nursing
authors: Giles, Amy; Prusinski, Regina; Wallace, Laura
subject: Nursing
abstract: This book encompasses the lifespan of those assigned female at birth (AFAB), focusing on contraception, preconception care, and preventive health care. It highlights the role of nurses as advocates for their patients.

title: Pharmacology for Nurses
authors: Barbour-Taylor, Tina; Mueller, Leah (Sabato); Paris, Donna; Weaver, Dorie
subject: Nursing; Pharmacology
abstract: This book aims to provide a fundamental understanding of the pharmacological use of drugs that a nurse needs to provide safe and effective care, reviewing the pathophysiology of various disease processes and the medications used in treatment.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Intellectual Property: An Economic Perspective
authors: Cuntz, Alexander; Fink, Carsten; Stamm, Hansueli
subject: Economics; Law; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper dissects AI's role as both a facilitator and disruptor of innovation and creativity, exploring the evolving landscape of AI innovation incentives and the challenges it poses to existing IP frameworks from an economic perspective.

title: Access to science and innovation in the developing world
authors: Muscarnera, Alessio; Cuntz, Alexander; Mueller-Langer, Frank; Scheufen, Marc; Oguguo, Prince C.
subject: Economics; Science Policy
abstract: This paper examines the implications of lowering barriers to online access to scientific publications for science and innovation in developing countries, finding that free or reduced-fee access increases scientific publication and clinical trials output.

title: Innovation Policies Under Economic Complexity
authors: Chacua, Christian; Hartog, Matte; Yildirim, Muhammed A.; Hausmann, Ricardo; Matha, Shreyas Gadgin
subject: Economics; Innovation Policy
abstract: This paper discusses the design of innovation policies to address current development challenges, arguing that effective policies should be place-based and multidimensional, leveraging countries' existing capabilities.

title: Global Trends in Innovation Patterns: A Complexity Approach

title: Computer Science for All? The Impact of High School Computer Science Courses on College Majors and Earnings
authors: Liu, Jing; Conrad, Cameron; Blazar, David
subject: Education; Computer Science; Economics
abstract: This study provides the first causal analysis of the impact of expanding Computer Science (CS) education in U.S. K-12 schools on students’ choice of college major and early career outcomes, finding positive effects on declaring a CS major, CS degree attainment, employment, and earnings, with larger benefits for underrepresented groups.

title: Old Moats for New Models: Openness, Control, and Competition in Generative AI
authors: Azoulay, Pierre; Krieger, Joshua L.; Nagaraj, Abhishek
subject: Artificial Intelligence; Economics; Innovation
abstract: This paper argues that while AI foundation models promise transformative impacts, tight control over complementary assets by incumbent firms will likely result in a concentrated market structure, stifling broad sectoral innovation.

title: 2024: The quest continues
subject: Biology; Publishing; Science Policy
abstract: This editorial for Open Biology describes the journal's efforts to make publishing less frustrating and more constructive, including joining Review Commons to streamline peer review, rewarding reviewers, and launching a new seminar series. It also announces an upcoming special issue on Evolutionary Cell Biology.

title: Economic Well-Being of U.S. Households in 2023
authors: Lloro, Alicia; Merry, Ellen; Dasgupta, Kabir; Larrimore, Jeff; Merchant, Zofsha; Shaalan, Fatimah; Tranfaglia, Anna
subject: Economics; Household Finance; Social Science
abstract: This report presents findings from the 2023 Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking (SHED). It indicates that overall financial well-being was nearly unchanged from the previous year but below the 2021 high. Many adults continued to report challenges from higher prices.

title: World Economic Situation and Prospects 2024
subject: Economics; Global Economy; Development
abstract: This report projects another tough year for the global economy, with sluggish growth, weak investment, and a spiraling debt crisis in many developing countries. It calls for large-scale investments to drive sustainable development and climate action.

title: How Does Data Access Shape Science? The Impact of Federal Statistical Research Data Centers on Economics Research
subject: Economics; Science Policy; Data Access
abstract: This paper studies how access to confidential microdata from the U.S. Census Bureau shapes the quantity, quality, and policy impact of economic research. It provides evidence on the benefits of broadening access to confidential data.

title: Open access and open science: some implications for the agricultural economics profession
authors: Fraser, Iain; Brooks, Jonathan; Bazzani, Claudia
subject: Agricultural Economics; Open Science; Publishing
abstract: This paper introduces a special issue on open access and open science, discussing emerging issues for applied economists. It covers topics like Plan S, the rise of hybrid publishing models, and the challenges academic societies face in this changing environment.

title: The Adolescent Mental Health Crisis: A Case Study in Family Court Planning
subject: Law; Family Law; Mental Health
abstract: This article addresses the adolescent mental health crisis within the framework of family court planning, particularly in the context of parental separation and divorce. It emphasizes the need for comprehensive planning processes to integrate Family Dispute Resolution (FDR) as a central strategy.

title: Amazon's Algorithmic Rents: The economics of information on Amazon
authors: Strauss, Ilan; O'Reilly, Tim; Mazzucato, Mariana
subject: Economics; Law; Technology
abstract: This paper argues that Amazon's business strategy has evolved to extract "algorithmic rents" from its third-party merchants via its advertising business. It critiques the standard antitrust model and shows how platforms can exploit information asymmetries to impair competition.

title: AI PROPULSION OF GLOBALIZATION: The Driving Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Global Expansion
subject: Economics; Political Science; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This senior thesis investigates and supports the argument that the development of artificial intelligence is propelling globalization. It examines how AI has shaped economies, governments, and societies, reducing barriers to trade and communication while challenging traditional nation-state models.

title: Open access research outputs receive more diverse citations
authors: Huang, Chun‐Kai; Neylon, Cameron; Montgomery, Lucy; et al.
subject: Bibliometrics; Open Science; Science Policy
abstract: By analyzing large-scale bibliographic data, this study finds a robust association between open access and increased diversity of citation sources by institutions, countries, and fields of research. Open access through repositories (Green OA) showed a stronger effect than via publisher platforms.

title: Open access journal publication in health and medical research and open science: benefits, challenges and limitations
authors: Logullo, Patricia; de Beyer, Jennifer A; Kirtley, Shona; et al.
subject: Medical Research; Open Science; Publishing
abstract: This paper summarizes the main benefits of open access, the routes for achieving it, and their challenges. It aims to help authors decide whether and how to choose open access for their health and medical research publications.

title: Food and Inequality
subject: Sociology; Food Studies; Public Health
abstract: This paper reviews sociological research on the relationship between food and inequality. It examines how food systems create, sustain, and exacerbate inequalities, as well as how food can be a site of resistance and social change.

title: Rehabilitating street children: The great paradox
subject: Sociology; Education; Social Work
source: International Journal of Sociology and Anthropology
abstract: This non-empirical paper explores the feasibility of rehabilitating street children through inclusive education. It highlights the paradox that even if rehabilitation is successful, the stigmatization of street children often leaves a lasting, seemingly insurmountable scar.

title: Evolving Publics and the Practice of Public Sociology
subject: Sociology; Social Theory
abstract: This analysis explores how the changing roles of diverse publics affect the practice of public sociology. Using examples from Du Bois to contemporary Brazil, it examines the challenges and opportunities created by the evolution of surrounding 'archipelagos of publics'.

title: The Sociological Imagination in Challenging Times
subject: Sociology; Education; Pedagogy
source: The Journal of Public and Professional Sociology
abstract: This critical essay argues that recent world events have made sociology more relevant to students' lives, increasing the need for a well-developed sociological imagination. It reviews the scholarship on this concept and provides recommendations for expanding the field.

title: The State of Sociology: Evidence from Dissertation Abstracts
subject: Sociology; Bibliometrics; Higher Education
abstract: This paper describes the state of sociology as practiced in U.S. PhD-granting departments by analyzing dissertation abstracts from 2020-2024. It finds that qualitative methods are more common than quantitative, and the most frequent topics are inequality, economics, and race.

title: Design anthropology for ethics of care and emergence: Reflections from an energy transition project
subject: Design; Anthropology; Ethics
abstract: This paper describes a design anthropology approach to design ethics, understanding ethics as relational and emergent. It illustrates how unexpected ethical issues emerged in an energy transition project, challenging the researchers to navigate conflicting stakeholder needs with care and empathy.

title: Deep hanging out, mixed methods toolkit, or something else? Current ethnographic practices in US anthropology
authors: Snodgrass, Jeffrey G.; Lacy, Michael G.; Wutich, Amber; et al.
subject: Anthropology; Research Methods; Ethnography
abstract: This study examines survey responses from AAA members about their practice and teaching of cultural anthropology research methods. It reveals distinctive methodological clusters, with "deep hanging out" and a "mixed methods toolkit" remaining prominent, and a commitment to advancing methods that account for power imbalances.

title: Environmental Science – Advances: reflections and welcome to another year of the journal
authors: Jones, Kevin C.; Cai, Zongwei; Manaia, Celia M.
subject: Environmental Science; Publishing
abstract: This editorial reflects on the journal's progress two years after its launch, highlighting its interdisciplinary scope, emerging topic trends, key metrics, and its recent acceptance for indexing in Web of Science. It also reaffirms the publisher's commitment to a 100% open access future.

title: Younger Candidates, More Voters: The Relationship Between Candidate Age and Youth Voter Turnout
subject: Political Science; Elections; Youth Studies
abstract: This paper examines the relationship between the average age of candidates in U.S. elections and youth voter turnout. Using regression analysis, it finds that while there is a positive correlation between candidate age and youth turnout, this relationship is significantly confounded by election type (presidential vs. midterm).

title: Not just by means alone: why the evolution of distribution shapes matters for understanding opinion dynamics. The case of the French reaction to the war in Ukraine
authors: Richter, Friederike; Thiébaut, Cyrille; Safra, Lou
subject: Political Science; Public Opinion; Data Analysis
abstract: This study illustrates how analyzing the evolution of both the mean and the distribution shape of survey responses can offer complementary insights into opinion dynamics. Using the French public's perception of defense issues before and after the war in Ukraine, it shows how this approach reveals nuanced shifts.

title: Political Issues in Social Media Campaigns for National Elections: A Plea for Comparative Research
authors: Bene, Márton; Magin, Melanie; Haßler, Jörg
subject: Political Science; Political Communication; Social Media
abstract: This editorial introduces a thematic issue examining how political parties use social media to promote issues during election campaigns. Based on a comparative research project covering 14 countries, it highlights diverse approaches to issue-based communication on social media.

title: Mary Warnock and 'public philosophy'
subject: Philosophy; Ethics; Public Policy
abstract: This article responds to the characterization of Mary Warnock as a public intellectual whose achievements came at the expense of philosophical rigor. It analyzes her view of ethics, the role of feelings in moral judgments, and her distinction between private and public moral attitudes, defending her against criticism.

title: Interpretative Phenomenological/Phronesis Analyses: Using Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) to Position Research Participant Experiential Narratives
authors: Md Syed, Md Azalanshah Bin; Wilson, Tony
subject: Philosophy; Research Methods; Hermeneutics
abstract: This paper proposes eight Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) derived from hermeneutic philosophers (Aristotle, Heidegger, Gadamer, Ricoeur) to systematically assist in the thematic analysis of experiential narratives within Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis (IPA).

title: Translation Notes: Heidegger, Derrida, and the Chance for (a) Philosophy
subject: Philosophy; Translation Studies; Deconstruction
abstract: This paper argues that translation is both a philosophical problem and a specific philosophical praxis. It considers the philosophies of Heidegger and Derrida, showing how Derrida's challenge to Heidegger's view of translation as a 'shipwreck' opens new paths for philosophical investigation.

title: Writing in Philosophy: Pedagogy and Practice
authors: Donovan, Sarah K. (ed.); Smith, Renée J. (ed.)
subject: Philosophy; Education; Pedagogy
abstract: This volume provides instructors with a resource for teaching writing in the philosophy classroom. It offers a variety of pedagogical approaches, including creative alternatives to traditional papers and strategies for inclusive practice, to help students develop essential writing skills for doing philosophy.

title: Introduction to Computer Science
subject: Computer Science; Programming; Data Structures
abstract: This textbook provides a comprehensive foundation in core computer science concepts, aligning with most introductory courses. It serves as an engaging entry point for students across various disciplines, offering a thorough introduction to computational thinking and its applications, from algorithms and data structures to software development and cybersecurity.

title: World Development Report 2024: The Middle-Income Trap
subject: Economics; Development; Public Policy
abstract: This report identifies pathways for developing economies to avoid the “middle-income trap.” It argues that middle-income countries must transition from investment-driven growth to infusing modern technologies and then to innovation, requiring significant restructuring of enterprise, work, and energy use.

title: Sustainability and Human Resources Management: Evaluating Challenges and Impacts for the Employee-Organization Relation
authors: Gomes, Daniel Roque (ed.); Ribeiro, Neuza (ed.); Santos, Maria João (ed.)
subject: Business; Human Resources; Sustainability
abstract: This book explores how sustainability can work alongside Human Resource Management (HRM) to achieve structural progress for organizations. It addresses the challenge of devising sustainable HRM practices that support organizational strategy, performance, and overall sustainable development.

title: Navigating micro- and nano-motors/swimmers with machine learning: Challenges and future directions
authors: Xue, Jueyi; Alinejad-Rokny, Hamid; Liang, Kang
subject: Machine Learning; Nanotechnology; Engineering
abstract: This review introduces the state-of-the-art machine learning techniques in micro-/nano-motor (MNM) research. It focuses on using machine learning to understand and manipulate the navigation and locomotion of MNMs, which have potential applications in fields like drug delivery and sensing.

title: Climate change scenarios forecast increased drought exposure for terrestrial vertebrates in the contiguous United States
authors: van den Bosch, M.; Costanza, J. K.; Peek, R. A.; Mola, J. M.; Steel, Z. L.
subject: Climate Change; Environmental Science; Biology
abstract: This study predicts the extent to which 1,221 terrestrial vertebrates in the contiguous US will be increasingly exposed to drought. On average, a 377% increase in annual drought exposure is anticipated by 2050–2080, with species in the southwestern US facing the largest increases.

title: Top 10 Public Health Challenges for 2024: Charting a New Direction for Global Health Security
authors: Lucero‐Prisno III, Don Eliseo; et al.
subject: Public Health; Health Policy
abstract: This article explores the top public health challenges for 2024, from infectious diseases and mental health to environmental sustainability and emerging technologies. It advocates for collective action, targeted interventions, and a commitment to prioritizing public health on a global scale.

title: Predicting Stock Trends Using Common Financial Indicators: A Summary of FedCSIS 2024 Data Science Challenge
subject: Data Science; Finance; Machine Learning
source: Annals of Computer Science and Information Systems
abstract: This paper describes the dataset and task for the FedCSIS 2024 Data Science Challenge, which focused on constructing predictive models for stock trend movements using fundamental financial data. It summarizes the outcomes and insights into the most successful machine learning techniques applied.

title: The unforeseen tide: exploring mental health impacts of the 2024 flash flood in Bangladesh
subject: Mental Health; Public Health; Disaster Management
abstract: This study examines the mental health impacts (depression, anxiety, stress) of the 2024 flash flood in Bangladesh. It found a high prevalence of mental health disorders among affected residents and identified key predictors, highlighting the urgent need for targeted mental health interventions and enhanced disaster preparedness.

title: Engagement and retention in digital mental health interventions: a narrative review
authors: Boucher, Eliane M.; Raiker, Joseph S.
subject: Mental Health; Digital Health; Psychology
abstract: This narrative review examines engagement and retention in digital mental health interventions (DMHIs). It finds that engagement rates are variable and comparable to traditional mental health care, and recommends adopting a common definition of engagement and focusing on outcomes rather than usage frequency.

abstract: This note examines how Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has affected female employment, revealing that gender gaps and occupational segregation have persisted and in some cases deepened, driven by entrenched gender norms and unequal care responsibilities.

title: Continuous Free Cortisol Profiles in Healthy Men: Validation of Microdialysis Method
authors: Bhake, Ragini; Russell, Georgina M.; Kershaw, Yvonne; et al.
subject: Medicine; Endocrinology; Physiology
source: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism
abstract: This is the first study validating a rapid sampling microdialysis method measuring free cortisol in the subcutaneous and blood compartments of healthy volunteers. It demonstrates the dynamic responses of total and free cortisol following stimulation and suppression.

title: LLM-Enhanced Reinforcement Learning: A Survey
subject: Reinforcement Learning; Machine Learning; Natural Language Processing
abstract: This paper presents the first comprehensive review in the emerging field of integrating LLMs into the Reinforcement Learning paradigm. We propose a structured taxonomy to systematically categorize LLMs within the classical agent-environment paradigm.

title: Introduction to Reinforcement Learning
subject: Reinforcement Learning; Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper provides an overview of Reinforcement Learning (RL), covering its core concepts, methodologies, and resources for further learning. It offers a thorough explanation of fundamental components such as states, actions, policies, and reward signals.

title: Variational Quantum Circuits Enhanced Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Shu, Runqiu; Xu, Xusheng; Yung, Man-Hong; Cui, Wei
subject: Generative Adversarial Networks; Quantum Computing; Machine Learning
abstract: We propose a hybrid quantum-classical architecture for improving GAN (QC-GAN). The generator consists of a quantum variational circuit with a one-layer neural network, and the discriminator is a traditional neural network.

title: Synthetic Brain Images: Bridging the Gap in Brain Mapping with Generative Adversarial Model
subject: Generative Adversarial Networks; Medical Imaging; Deep Learning
abstract: This work investigates the use of Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks (DCGAN) for producing high-fidelity and realistic MRI image slices. The generator network learns to synthesise realistic MRI image slices from a dataset of brain scans.

title: State of Geographic Access to Cancer Treatment Trials in the United States
subject: Clinical Trials; Oncology; Public Health
abstract: Most US counties have limited to no trial offerings, a disparity magnified in counties that are nonmetropolitan, with high social vulnerability, and with high cancer mortality. Effort to facilitate diverse site participation is needed to promote equitable access.

title: Large language models in medicine: A review of current clinical trials
subject: Clinical Trials; Natural Language Processing; Healthcare
abstract: This review analyzes current clinical trials investigating large language models' (LLMs) applications in healthcare. We identified 27 trials (5 published and 22 ongoing) across 4 main clinical applications: patient care, data handling, decision support, and research assistance.

title: The role of Open Access Data in democratizing healthcare AI
subject: Public Health; Artificial Intelligence; Healthcare Policy
abstract: This article discusses how Open Access Data can help democratize healthcare AI, enhancing research, improving patient well-being, and promoting treatment equity, with a focus on Andalusia, Spain.

title: Exploring the rise and diversity of health and societal issues that use a public health approach
subject: Public Health; Health Policy
abstract: This scoping review identifies and categorizes issues discussing a "public health approach" in literature since 2010. We identified 28 categories where such an approach is advocated, but found that its operationalisation varied extensively.

title: Social science to accelerate coastal adaptation to sea-level rise
subject: Social Science; Climate Change; Environmental Science
abstract: This scoping review explores how social sciences support coastal adaptation to sea-level rise. We show that Political Sciences, Economics, Sociology and Geography are already supporting coastal adaptation, but other fields are less developed in this context.

title: A Smol Perspective: Internet Sociolinguistics and the Border Between Written and Spoken Word
subject: Humanities; Linguistics; Sociology
abstract: The internet and its users complicate the idea of a clear separation between written and spoken language. This paper demonstrates how the line between these two means of communication are more muddled than previously understood.

title: The Value of the Humanities: Understanding the Career Destinations of Oxford Humanities Graduates
subject: Humanities; Education; Economics
abstract: This report is a detailed study of the career destinations of over 9,000 humanities graduates from Oxford. The findings confirm that the skills conferred by studying a humanities subject can transform working life and the wider world.

title: Public Access to Scientific Research Findings and Principles of Biomedical Research
subject: Science Policy; Medicine
abstract: This editorial discusses a new policy for the JAMA Network regarding public access to scientific research findings and the principles of biomedical research.

title: Peer reviewers from low- and middle-income countries for open access journals in oncology
subject: Oncology; Science Policy; Public Health
abstract: This paper outlines the impediments for cancer research and publication from low-and middle-income countries (LMIC), noting that article publishing charges (APC) are unaffordable for many, and argues that engaging peer reviewers from LMICs can increase diversity.

title: From data strategy to implementation to advance cancer research and cancer care
subject: Oncology; Data Science; Health Informatics
abstract: In a comprehensive cancer center, effective data strategies are essential to evaluate practices, understand the disease, and develop better treatments. This paper discusses data collection, analysis using NLP, and secure data sharing strategies.

title: Cardiology researchers' practices and perceived barriers to open science: an international survey
subject: Cardiology; Science Policy
abstract: We survey an international group of researchers publishing in cardiovascular journals regarding their perceptions and practices related to open science, finding that funding was the most essential incentive to adopt open science practices.

title: Role of open access echocardiography in detection of cardiac structural and functional abnormalities
subject: Cardiology; Health Services
abstract: To evaluate the prevalence of significant structural heart disease in patients referred by general practitioners using open access echocardiography. Major structural and functional cardiac abnormalities are common in late middle-aged patients.

title: Imaging Neuroscience opening editorial
subject: Neurology; Neuroscience; Science Policy
abstract: This editorial introduces a new non-profit open access journal, Imaging Neuroscience, launched by former editors of NeuroImage in response to what they considered unethical and unsustainable publication fees.

title: Open access repository-scale propagated nearest neighbor suspect spectral library for untargeted metabolomics
subject: Metabolomics; Bioinformatics; Immunology
abstract: Untargeted mass spectrometry-based metabolomics is a powerful tool for studying the role of small molecules in biological systems. We present a nearest neighbor suspect spectral library to expand metabolite annotation capabilities beyond existing experimental spectral libraries.

title: Aerobiology-A New Open Access Journal
subject: Aerobiology; Publishing; Immunology
abstract: This editorial introduces a new open access journal titled 'Aerobiology', which will cover research on the airborne dispersal of biological particles.

title: JASPAR 2024: 20th anniversary of the open-access database of transcription factor binding profiles
subject: Bioinformatics; Genomics; Databases
abstract: JASPAR is a widely-used open-access database of DNA-binding profiles for transcription factors. In this 10th release, the CORE collection has expanded with 329 new profiles, a 20% increase from the previous release.

title: Development of an open access, virtual bioinformatics lab for students in medical laboratory sciences
authors: Fukuto, Hana S.; Viboud, Gloria I.
subject: Bioinformatics; Education; Medical Laboratory Science
abstract: We developed and assessed a virtual laboratory learning unit to introduce basic bioinformatics concepts and tools to medical laboratory sciences (MLS) students. The unit is a promising tool and is available as an open educational resource.

title: GetGenome: Overcoming inequalities in access to genomics technology
authors: Canham, James; Win, Joe; GetGenome Network; Kamoun, Sophien
subject: Genomics; Science Policy; Global Health
abstract: Although genomics has become integral to life science research, inequitable access to genomics technology remains prevalent. GetGenome, a non-profit organization, aims to overcome this by providing equitable access to genomics technology and training.

title: Symbiotic revolutions at the interface of genomics and microbiology
subject: Genomics; Microbiology; Symbiosis
abstract: Symbiosis is an old idea with a contentious history. New genomic technologies and research paradigms are fueling a shift in some of its central tenets; we need to be humble and open-minded about what the data are telling us.

title: A novel open-access artificial-intelligence-driven platform for CNS drug discovery utilizing adult zebrafish
subject: Drug Discovery; Artificial Intelligence; Neuroscience
